Note: All texts, based on Macer, show variations. For comparable verse texts cf. 417.8, 2519, and 5877.
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, Society of Antiquaries 101: Latin text: ‘Virtutes betonice’.
_description: ‘A tretys of diverse herbis’ especially Betony — in short couplets

BodAsh1477.First Lines:
To telle of beten I have great meyndeAnd sithen of herbis that I
                    fynde…
BodAsh1477.Last Lines:
…Who so hath betayn & [a space is left blank
                    here]With his vryne it shall out goon

BodAsh1397.First Lines:
To tellen of bytayne I have grete myndeAnd sythen of othur herbys
                    os I fynde…
BodAsh1397.Last Lines:
…ffor al maner of euyllys it is gode on groundeych stounde
                    whyle it mai on erthe be founde
BodAsh1397.Attributed Title:
Here be gynnyt a tretys of diuerse herbis & furst of Bytayne (f.
                        117v)
BodAsh1397.Editions:
Rohde,  Eleanor Sinclair. 
             The Old English Herbals.
         London, New York: Longman, Green, 1922: 43-4, 193-6 (extracts).

CULDd1044.First Lines:
Off herbys now I wyll yow telle by & byAs I fynde wrytyn in a
                    boke…
CULDd1044.Last Lines:
…It distroyeth the morfewAnd dispoyling to þe
                    lepyr
CULDd1044.Note:
Written as prose, but highlighted capital marks each verse
                    line.
CULDd1044.Editions:
Rohde,  Eleanor Sinclair. 
             The Old English Herbals.
         London, New York: Longman, Green, 1922: 43-4, 193-6 (extracts).

CamMagPep1661.First Lines:
Of herbis xxvi xxiiiiti [sic]I wil ȝou
                    tellyn by and bi…
CamMagPep1661.Last Lines:
…And of posteis & of bloodAs knowyn wel þese clerkys
                    good
CamMagPep1661.Note:
Written as prose; first line written rubric immediately following rubric
                    heading ‘Betonica’ (p. 288); no indication of new work at top p. 309
                    when changes to prose.

CamTCC905.First Lines:
Astrologye ther been of hem toothe longe & the round
                    also…
CamTCC905.Last Lines:
…Of Saryseynys of Iues of englysch bokes worthywele preuyd
                    & Iugyd sothe & Iustly
CamTCC905.Note:
Extract formerly listed separately as 417.8 (see Keiser (1996)
XKeiser,  George R. 
             “Reconstructing Robert Thornton’s Herbal.” 
             Medium Ævum
         65 (1996): 35-53, 51, n. 5); at end, Latin instruction: ‘fflores
                        eius manduca per iii dies & illo Anno nolime tangere nec lepra nec alia
                        Apostomata habebis’ (f. 148).

CamTCC921.First Lines:
To telle of betoygne I haue gret myndeAnd of other erbes as I
                    fynde…
CamTCC921.Last Lines:
…He castith wele to þe eyne sightThys medecyne ys prouede
                    I the plight

CamTCC1117.First Lines:
To tell of beten I haue myndeAnd sethyn of oþer herbes as I
                    fynde…
CamTCC1117.Last Lines:
…there shall no drede hym wakeTyll fro vnder ys hede it be
                    take

BLAdd17866.First Lines: Moder of gresseqwo so hem sekesSays Ipocrus ere vnset lekesIn lechecraft many & feleSeke men with þem to hele…
BLAdd17866.Last Lines: …He cast to þe eye wel þe syghtThys medcyne is proued well a plyght
BLAdd17866.Note: Variant beginning; followed immediately by 2343 without break.

BLAdd60577.First Lines:
…Mary golde ys an herbe full gracyouseWho so knowethe all his
                    vertuouse…
BLAdd60577.Last Lines:
…þu shalt bothe knowe & seeAll the condycyoun whate
                    they be…
BLAdd60577.Note:
Equivalent to lines 148-88 of London,  British Library Addit. 17866; treated here as
                    separate work with initial and explicit.
BLAdd60577.Editions:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             “Introduction.” 
             The Winchester Anthology. A Facsimile of British Library Additional
                Manuscript 60577. With an account of the music by 
                    Iain
                    Fenlon. 
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1981.

BLSl140.First Lines:
Macer of erbe who so hem sekisSeth ypocras on sett
                    lekis…
BLSl140.Last Lines:
…Þe flowre ys red þe smell ys soteTo euery sore hit
                    may do bote
BLSl140.Attributed Title:
Here begynnyth the boke of the doctor Macer of þe vertue (f.
                    52)

BLSl147.Editions:
Rohde,  Eleanor Sinclair. 
             The Old English Herbals.
         London, New York: Longman, Green, 1922: 43-4, 193-6 (extracts).

Lincoln91.Editions:
Keiser,  George R. 
             “Reconstructing Robert Thornton’s Herbal.” 
             Medium Ævum
         65 (1996): 35-53: 37-8.

YorkMinXVIE32.First Lines:
…To telle of beteyn I haue gret myndeAn sithen of oþer
                    herbes als I fynde…
YorkMinXVIE32.Last Lines:
…For al maner of euil he is god ilk stoundeWhilk þat may
                    on erth be founde…
YorkMinXVIE32.Editions:
Powell,  Susan. 
             “Another Manuscript of Index of Middle English Verse No. 2627.” 
             Notes and Queries
         n.s.34 [232] (1987): 154-6: 155-6.

PierpontB21.First Lines:
These lechys for seke mannys sakeDiuers medicynys sum tyme gun
                    makeOf all þe gressys þat growyn on Roteþat mown man
                    & woman helpyn to bote…
PierpontB21.Last Lines:
…Of his stalke it beryth a blak seedþat is good for
                    þe swynesy at ned
PierpontB21.Editions:
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “A Middle English Medical Manuscript from Norwich.” 
             Studies in Medieval Literature in Honor of Professor Albert Cross
                Baugh.
            MacEdward Leach, ed. 
         Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1961: 285-98: 289-93 (extracts).

Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.
